node.text:
50 years after the War On Drugs began, we are acutely aware of how it not only failed our communities but harmed millions of people in the process.

On June 17, Last Prisoner Project partnered with @dream.corps and @weldonangelos for an evening of action featuring policymakers and activists. LPP’s Director of Strategic Initiatives, Natalie Papillion, and Legacy Fellow @dontewest joined with leaders in the space to discuss uplifting the voices of targeted communities, rectifying old wrongs, and organizing equitable drug policy reform.

If you missed the event, watch the highlights here, then visit https://www.lastprisonerproject.org/take-action to learn how you can use your voice to #EndTheWarOnDrugs.

node.title: 50 Years of Injustice: It’s Time To End the War on Drugs

node.text:
With her dad and best friend, Ricardo Ashmeade, currently serving a 22-year sentence for marijuana, Richeda Ashmeade sheds light on the injustice and pain his imprisonment has had on her family — and so many others like them.⁣ #FreeRicardoAshmeade
⁣
🎥: @galen.oakes

node.title: In Her Words: A Father Lost to Cannabis Prohibition

node.text: Natalie Papillion, Last Prisoner Project’s Director of Strategic Initiatives, discusses the racist origins - and devastating implications of - marijuana prohibition on #turningpointabc. 📺 Watch the full segment via the link in our bio. @abcnews @ashan @nightline

node.title: Turning Point: Cannabis & Justice For All?

node.text:
In 2017, after Governor Murphy stated that in his first 90 days in office he would fully legalize marijuana, Mario Ramos, a longtime cannabis advocate and activist, started growing marijuana plants in the hopes of being able to enter the newly legal industry. Despite being a legacy operator in the industry, rather than find opportunity in New Jersey, Mario was prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law.

After spending two years in custody, just days after New Jersey voters approved the ballot initiative to legalize adult-use, Mario was sentenced to seven years in prison for conspiracy to manufacture marijuana.

Luckily he was afforded the opportunity to serve out the remainder of his sentence at home under New Jersey's Intensive Supervision Program. With this opportunity Mario is advocating for the release of all New Jersey cannabis prisoners through executive clemency. 

Learn more about our New Jersey Clemency Campaign at the link in bio and join us Friday at 530 PT/ 830 ET for a conversation with Mario and LPP Legacy Fellow @dontewest right here on our IG Live.

@ibudyouinc

node.title: Mario Ramos Speaks on Cannabis Clemency in New Jersey

node.text:
We loved getting to celebrate the first birthday out of prison for @mtfree.2021 in over 25 years! We are so grateful for Michael’s freedom, and for his continued commitment to using his voice to advocate for change. 

Huge thank you to all of Michael’s supporters and especially @crescocannabis @fluresh @curaleaf.usa @rosemaryjaneco @ubaked2 @micannabischefs and the incomparable @marybailey_onthemove @gburgz and Deedee Kirkwood for making this celebration so special. 

Happy 70th Michael!💚🎉

node.title: First Birthday in More Than 20 Years

node.accessibility_caption: Rudi Gammo posing with his wife and three children. Text reads Rudi Gammo serving 5.5 years for operating a medical cannabis dispensary.

node.text:
Rudi Gammo is a proud husband and father of three from Detroit, MI. He’s also an LPP constituent imprisoned for cannabis. This is his story.⁣
⁣
In 2018, Michigan became the first state in the midwest to legalize the possession and sale of cannabis for adult use. But that year, Rudi was sentenced to 5.5 years in prison for operating a city-sanctioned medical cannabis dispensary in Detroit.⁣
⁣
Three years later, he is still fighting for his freedom while others are freely profiting from the sale of cannabis. Rudi’s clemency petition was submitted in 2020, but Governor Whitmer has failed to act. Not only that but soon after Rudi battled COVID-19, he learned his son, Santino, was diagnosed with Leukemia.⁣
⁣
“It’s been so hard this year, because of the pandemic,” says Rudi, “for [incarcerated parents] to stay connected to their kids. We only get non-contact visits and video visitation. The prison has limited the number of visits. It’s torture to know that the world is going back to normal but they still have separate guidelines for prisons, despite 80% of the prison population and staff having been vaccinated.⁣
⁣
“There are a lot of fathers in the world that don't spend time with their kids by choice, but here I am fighting every day to be back in their lives. When I wake up every day the first thing on my mind is ‘what can I do today to get myself home to my kids?’”⁣
⁣
✉️ : Send Rudi a letter of support by visiting https://www.lastprisonerproject.org/letter-writing-program⁣
⁣
#freecannabisprisoners

Last Prisoner Project Graphic with a photo of our constituent Humberto Ramirez, who is currently serving 7 years for cannabis.

node.text:
In November 2020, just days after voters overwhelmingly approved legalizing cannabis for adult use, Humberto Ramirez was sentenced to 7 years in prison for having 6 lbs of marijuana in his trunk.⁣
⁣
That day, Humberto and his family — including fiance Brooke Anne and daughters Chanel, Taina, and Lily — had their worlds “shattered.” While Humberto is aware of his mistake, he never imagined it would cost him so much.⁣
⁣
“My experience as an incarcerated father has been heartbreaking,” says Humberto. “Not being there for my daughters physically hurts me to my soul.”⁣
⁣
To remain present in their lives, Humberto calls home daily and sees them once a week via video. But this is a stark contrast to the life he lived up until this point, where he never missed a carpool run, dance recital, or competition.⁣
⁣
His fiance Brooke Anne describes Humberto as a “hardworking, loving, and present father” and “the best man any woman could ask for.” When Brooke Anne wanted to pursue her dreams of becoming a nurse, he supported her 100%. For 6 years, when she would come home from work exhausted, Humberto would have dinner waiting with a smile.⁣
⁣
Last Prisoner Project is urging @govmurphy to reunite Humberto with his family by granting him — and all of New Jersey’s cannabis prisoners — clemency. Show your support by signing your name to our petition via the link in our bio.⁣
⁣
#FreeCannabisPrisoners #SendHumbertoRamirezHome

node.text: Did you know that law enforcement can take anything from the $10 in your wallet to your very own *home* without ever charging you with a crime? Here’s how.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Last Prisoner Project on July 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'YOU ASKED: What is civil asset forfeiture? And is it really legal?'.

Photo by Last Prisoner Project on July 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Civil asset forfeiture Civil asset forfeiture is a tool that allows law enforcement to seize any property they allege is involved in criminal activity. Cash, cars, homes, and other valuables can be taken without the owner being arrested or convicted of a crime. The government can then choose to keep or sell the property._ (And yes, it is legal.)'.

Photo by Last Prisoner Project on July 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says '"Many police departments use forfeiture to benefit their bottom lines, making seizures motivated by profit rather than crime-fighting. For people whose property has been seized through civil asset forfeiture, legally regaining such property is notoriously difficult and expensive, with costs sometimes exceeding the value of the property. ACLU'.

Photo by Last Prisoner Project on July 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The financial benefit of this practice has led to the over-policing of crimes that carry a high possibility of forfeiture (most predominantly minor drug offenses) to the neglect of other crimes that actually impact public safety. Cannabis consumers are a common target, especially low-income individuals who do not have the means to legally challenge the seizure of their property. Prior to the War on Drugs, civil asset forfeiture was rarely used.'.
Photo by Last Prisoner Project on July 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'As of 2017, the Department of Justice Assets Forfeiture Fund topped a record $8.2 billion. DRUG POLICY ALLIANCE'.

node.text: Marijuana has been used as a scapegoat for 50 years of police brutality. This has never been a "War on Drugs," it is a War on People — and it must end now.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Last Prisoner Project on July 12, 2021 tagging @dontewest. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'MEET THE TEAM LPP is family. Our brothers and sisters are still incarcerated for cannabis and we must get them home. You don't leave your family behind." CHAN GE IS COMING. ត Donte West Legacy Fellow PRISONER PRISONER ONER PROJECT'.

node.text:
Donte West (@dontewest) is an advocate for cannabis policy and criminal justice reform whose experience being incarcerated on cannabis charges changed his life forever. 👇🏾⁣
⁣
In 2018 Donte (then 23) was arrested on marijuana-related offenses — despite having no marijuana in his possession or any proof of intent to distribute. He was sentenced to 7 years and 8 months in prison.⁣
⁣
Donte spent the next 3 years working with his prison’s warden and staff to fight his charges. He also used this time to speak to area teens about his experience with law enforcement and the courts.⁣
⁣
Donte was eventually released October 15,2020 and exonerated on Mach 21, 2021. He is now re-establishing his life and working with LPP to help free anyone incarcerated on cannabis-related charges.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Last Prisoner Project on July 09, 2021 tagging @usatoday. May be an image of text that says 'USA TODAY July 1, 2021 Cannabis Pinmn reform? It's the right time Ûor full federal legalization to help economy and people PRIS PRINR NER PROJECT'.

node.text:
"Not only are we wrongly imprisoning tens of thousands of people a year – who are convicted of an activity that is no longer a crime – but we are also spending billions of dollars trying to enforce an antiquated movement that has disproportionately affected communities of color, and no longer represents the views of the overwhelming majority of American people."⁣
⁣
Read the entire @usatoday article via the link in our bio ⚡️
